If \(n\) is a composite integer and \(2^n ≡ 2 \bmod n\), then \(n\) is a pseudoprime. If \(n\) is a composite integer and \(b^n ≡ b \bmod n \), then \(n \) is a pseudoprime to the base \(b\).

If \(n\) is a composite integer, and \(b^n ≡ b \bmod n\) for all integers \(b\), then \(n\) is an absolute pseudoprime or Carmichael number.

It can be manually checked that \(2^3 ≡ 2 \bmod 3\). We can raise both sides by 11, and then by 17:

$$\begin{gather} (2^3)^{11} ≡ 2^{11} \bmod 3 \\ 2^{(3)(11)} ≡ 2 \bmod 3 \\ (2^{(3)(11)})^{17} ≡ 2^{17} \bmod 3 \\ 2^{(3)(11)(17)} ≡ 2 \bmod 3 \end{gather}$$

It can be manually checked that \(2^{17} ≡ 7 \bmod 11\). We can raise both sides by 3, and then by 11:

$$\begin{gather} (2^{17})^3 ≡ 7^3 \bmod 11 \\ (2^{(17)(3)}) ≡ 2 \bmod 11 \\ (2^{(17)(3)})^{11} ≡ 2^{11} \bmod 11 \\ 2^{(17)(3)(11)} ≡ 2 \bmod 11 \end{gather}$$

It can be manually checked that \(2^{17} ≡ 2 \bmod 17\). We can raise both sides by 11, and then by 3:

$$\begin{gather} (2^{17})^{11} ≡ 2^{11} \bmod 17 \\ (2^{(17)(11)}) ≡ 8 \bmod 17 \\ (2^{(17)(11)})^{3} ≡ 8^3 \bmod 17 \\ 2^{(17)(3)(11)} ≡ 2 \bmod 17 \end{gather}$$

We have concluded three things:

$$\begin{gather} 2^{(3)(11)(17)} ≡ 2 \bmod 3 \\ 2^{(17)(3)(11)} ≡ 2 \bmod 11 \\ 2^{(17)(3)(11)} ≡ 2 \bmod 17 \end{gather}$$

Since \((3,11) = 1\):

$$\begin{gather} 2^{(3)(11)(17)} ≡ 2 \bmod (3*11) \\ 2^{(3)(11)(17)} ≡ 2 \bmod 33 \end{gather}$$

Since \((17, 33) = 1\):

$$\begin{gather} 2^{(3)(11)(17)} ≡ 2 \bmod (33 * 17) \\ 2^{(3)(11)(17)} ≡ 2 \bmod (3)(11)(17) \end{gather}$$

This shows that \((3)(11)(17) = 561\) is a pseudoprime.
Prove that 91 is pseudoprime to the base 3.

If 91 were to be a pseudoprime to the base 3, then:

$$ 3^{91} ≡ 3 \bmod 91 $$

Let's see if this is true. We can manually check that \(3^{10} ≡ 81 \bmod 91\). If we square both sides:

$$\begin{align} (3^{10})^2 &≡ 81^2 ≡ 6561 \bmod 91 \\ 3^{20} &≡ 9 \bmod 91 \end{align}$$

If we raise both sides to the power of 4:

$$\begin{align} (3^{20})^4 &≡ 9^4 ≡ 6561 \bmod 91 \\ 3^{80} &≡ 9 \bmod 91 \end{align}$$

This means:

$$\begin{align} 3^{80} 3^{10} 3 &≡ (9) (81) (3) \bmod 91 \\ 3^{91} &≡ 2187 ≡ 3 \bmod 91 \end{align}$$

We have shown that \(3^{91} ≡ 3 \bmod 91\).
Let \(n\) be a pseudoprime. Prove that \(m = 2^n - 1\) is also a pseudoprime.

By definition of a pseudoprime:

$$\begin{gather} 2^n ≡ 2 \bmod n \\ nk = 2^n -2 \end{gather}$$

We can rewrite this as:

$$\begin{gather} nk = 2^n - 1 - 1 \\ nk = m - 1 \\ nk + 1 = m \end{gather}$$

Since \(m = 2^n - 1\):

$$\begin{gather} 2^n ≡ 1 \bmod m \\ (2^n)^k ≡ 1^k \bmod m \\ (2^{nk}) ≡ 1 \bmod m \end{gather}$$

We can multiply both sides by 2:

$$\begin{gather} (2^{nk})2 ≡ 2 \bmod m \\ 2^{nk+1} ≡ 2 \bmod m \\ 2^m ≡ 2 \bmod m \end{gather}$$

This shows that \(m\) is also a pseudoprime.

If 561 is pseudoprime, then \(b^561 ≡ b \bmod 561\) for all integers \(b\).

The prime factors of 561 are 3, 11 and 17. There are two cases to consider, one where 3, 11 and 17 do not divide \(b\), so \(b\) is coprime to all of them, and the other case is where at least one of 3, 11 or 17 divides \(b\).

Let's consider the first case. By Fermat's little theorem, we can claim:

$$\begin{gather} b^2 ≡ 1 \bmod 3 \\ b^{10} ≡ 1 \bmod 11 \\ b^{16} ≡ 1 \bmod 17 \end{gather}$$

We can raise both sides so that the exponent of \(b\) is 560.

$$\begin{gather} (b^2)^{280} ≡ 1^{280} ≡ b^{560} ≡ 1 \bmod 3 \\ (b^{10})^{56} ≡ 1^{56} ≡ b^{560} ≡ 1 \bmod 11 \\ (b^{16})^{35} ≡ 1^{35} ≡ b^{560} ≡ 1 \bmod 17 \end{gather}$$

Since 3, 11 and 17 are pairwise coprime:

$$\begin{gather} b^{560} ≡ 1 \bmod (3)(11)(17) \\ b^{560} ≡ 1 \bmod 561 \\ b^{561} ≡ b \bmod 561 \end{gather}$$

Thus, we have shown that 561 is an absolute pseudoprime if 3, 11 or 17 do not divide \(b\). Now let's consider the second case where at least one of them do divide \(b\), then:

$$\begin{gather} b^{561} ≡ b \bmod 3 \\ b^{561} ≡ b \bmod 11 \\ b^{561} ≡ b \bmod 17 \end{gather}$$

This is true because if \(p\) is either 3, 11 or 17, and it divides \(b\), then \(b^{561} ≡ b ≡ 0 \bmod p\), but if it doesn't divide \(b\) then \(b^{560} ≡ 1 \implies b^{561} ≡ b\). This means:

$$\begin{gather} b^{561} ≡ b \bmod (3)(11)(17) \\ b^{561} ≡ b \bmod 561 \end{gather}$$

It both cases, we have shown that 561 is a pseudoprime.
